description: Number of 3-infinitary divisors of n: if n = Product p(i)^r(i) and d = Product p(i)^s(i), each s(i) has a digit a <= b in its ternary expansion everywhere that the corresponding r(i) has a digit b, then d is a 3-infinitary-divisor of n.
comments: Multiplicative: If e = sum d_k 3^k, then a(p^e) = prod (d_k+1). - _Christian G. Bower_, May 19 2005
links: J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles
example: 2^3*3 is a 3-infinitary-divisor of 2^5*3^2 because 2^3*3 = 2^10*3^1 and 2^5*3^2 = 2^12*3^2 in ternary expanded power. All corresponding digits satisfy the condition. 1<=1, 0<=2, 1<=2.
maple: A038148 := proc(n) if n= 1 then 1; else ifa := ifactors(n)[2] ;a := 1; for f in ifa do e := convert(op(2,f),base,3) ; a := a*mul(d+1,d=e) ; end do: end if; end proc:seq(A038148(n),n=1..50) ; # _R. J. Mathar_, Feb 08 2011
mathematica: a[1] = 1; a[n_] := (k = 1; Do[k = k * Times @@ (IntegerDigits[f, 3] + 1), {f, FactorInteger[n][[All, 2]]}]; k); Table[a[n], {n, 1, 102}](* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Feb 03 2012, after _R. J. Mathar_ *)
author: _Yasutoshi Kohmoto_
